thread.title: U.S. Stock Index Futures Climb as Fed Bets Wane; Goldman Slips
thread.title_full: U.S. Stock Index Futures Climb as Fed Bets Wane; Goldman Slips - Bloomberg Business

author: Bloomberg.com
title: U.S. Stock Index Futures Climb as Fed Bets Wane; Goldman Slips
text:
U.S. stock-index futures climbed after signs of weakness in the global economy improved the odds of the Federal Reserve maintaining record low interest rates for longer.
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. declined 1.4 percent after quarterly results missed analysts’ expectations as the global market turmoil took a bigger toll on its trading revenue than at rivals. Netflix Inc. fell 3.2 percent after its quarterly U.S. subscriber growth missed estimates. Philip Morris International Inc. added 2.1 percent topped quarterly profit estimates.
S&P 500 E-mini contracts expiring in December rose 0.7 percent to 1,997.25 at 7:55 a.m. in New York, after a two-day drop for the underlying gauge. The benchmark measure rallied last week by the most since December, following its worst quarterly rout since 2011. Dow Jones Industrial Average contracts rose 76 points, or 0.5 percent, to 16,898 today.
“Today seems to be about positive momentum, following a couple of down days, on the absence of negative news and a few positive snippets - China reform hopes and the Fed speculation,” said Frances Hudson, a global thematic strategist at Standard Life Investments in Edinburgh. Her firm manages $393.1 billion. “The timing of the U.S. Fed on rates probably influences sentiment rather than fundamentals.”
A worse-than-forecast U.S. retail sales report yesterday compounded pessimism from disappointing data on China’s economy, sending the probability of an October rate increase to 6 percent, from 10 percent last week. April is now the first month for which traders are pricing in at least even odds of a liftoff. Asian stocks rallied after China’s plan to reorganize its telecom industry raised speculation of accelerated reforms of state-owned companies.
Fed Remarks Investors will get more data today to help assess the trajectory of U.S. interest rates from reports on initial jobless claims, consumer prices and manufacturing in the New York area. Regional Fed chiefs including St. Louis’s James Bullard, New York’s William C. Dudley and Cleveland’s Loretta Mester are also scheduled to speak.
Analysts forecast earnings for S&P 500 members dropped 7.2 percent in the third quarter. Disappointing results from JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. shock forecast that profit will slump dragged shares lower yesterday.
“A decline in profits is not so problematic for markets as long as it is expected,” said Standard Life’s Hudson. “The trend has been for OK earnings but disappointing revenues. It’s too early to say which way things will go.”
Manitowoc Co. tumbled 14 percent after its quarterly preliminary sales missed projections and the maker of construction equipment cut its annual forecast for revenue from cranes. Garmin Ltd. slid 11 percent after lowering its full-year profit and sales targets.
